nodes.label: Concurrency
nodes.title: Concurrency
nodes.description: Concurrency:

nodes.label: Thread abstraction relative tconcurrency
nodes.title: Thread abstraction relative tconcurrency
nodes.description: Thread abstraction relative tconcurrency: provides a concurrent execution unit within a process, enabling parallelism and concurrency.

nodes.label: Race conditions, critical sections (role of interrupts if needed)
nodes.title: Race conditions, critical sections (role of interrupts if needed)
nodes.description: Race conditions, critical sections (role of interrupts if needed): occur when multiple threads access shared resources concurrently, leading to unpredictable behavior, which interrupts may exacerbate.

nodes.label: Deadlocks and starvation
nodes.title: Deadlocks and starvation
nodes.description: Deadlocks and starvation: are synchronization problems where threads are unable to proceed due to circular dependencies or resource starvation.

nodes.label: Multiprocessor issues
nodes.title: Multiprocessor issues
nodes.description: Multiprocessor issues: (spin-locks, reentrancy)

nodes.label: Thread creation, states, structures
nodes.title: Thread creation, states, structures
nodes.description: Thread creation, states, structures: define the lifecycle and properties of threads, including creation, execution, and termination.

nodes.label: Thread APIs
nodes.title: Thread APIs
nodes.description: Thread APIs: provide functions and interfaces for managing threads, including creation, synchronization, and communication.

nodes.label: Deadlocks and starvation
nodes.title: Deadlocks and starvation
nodes.description: Deadlocks and starvation:  (necessary conditions/mitigations)

nodes.label: Implementing thread safe code
nodes.title: Implementing thread safe code
nodes.description: Implementing thread safe code: (semaphores, mutex locks, cond vars)

nodes.label: Race conditions in shared memory
nodes.title: Race conditions in shared memory
nodes.description: Race conditions in shared memory: occur when multiple threads access shared data concurrently without proper synchronization, leading to inconsistencies and errors in the program's behavior.

nodes.label: Scheduling
nodes.title: Scheduling
nodes.description: Scheduling: involves the allocation of resources to tasks or processes over time, determining their execution order and duration.

nodes.label: Preemptive and non-preemptive scheduling
nodes.title: Preemptive and non-preemptive scheduling
nodes.description: Preemptive and non-preemptive scheduling: allows a higher-priority task to interrupt the execution of a lower-priority task, while non-preemptive scheduling does not allow interruptions.

nodes.label: Timers
nodes.title: Timers
nodes.description: Timers: (e.g. building many timers out of finite hardware timers)

nodes.label: Schedulers and policies
nodes.title: Schedulers and policies
nodes.description: Schedulers and policies: govern the decision-making process of allocating resources and prioritizing tasks, based on factors such as priority, fairness, and efficiency.

nodes.label: Concepts of SMP/multiprocessor scheduling
nodes.title: Concepts of SMP/multiprocessor scheduling
nodes.description: Concepts of SMP/multiprocessor scheduling : involves coordinating the execution of tasks across multiple processors or cores in symmetric multiprocessing (SMP) systems

nodes.label: Process Model
nodes.title: Process Model
nodes.description: Process Model: defines the structure and behavior of processes, including their creation, execution, and termination.

nodes.label: Processes and threads relative tvirtualization-Protected memory, process state, memory isolation, etc
nodes.title: Processes and threads relative tvirtualization-Protected memory, process state, memory isolation, etc
nodes.description: Processes and threads relative tvirtualization-Protected memory, process state, memory isolation, etc:

nodes.label: Memory footprint/segmentation (stack, heap, etc)
nodes.title: Memory footprint/segmentation (stack, heap, etc)
nodes.description: Memory footprint/segmentation (stack, heap, etc): involve organizing memory into distinct regions such as stack, heap, and code segments to manage memory usage efficiently.

nodes.label: Creating and loading executables and shared libraries
nodes.title: Creating and loading executables and shared libraries
nodes.description: Creating and loading executables and shared libraries: Examples: 1, Dynamic linking, GOT, PLT. 2, Structure of modern executable formats like ELF

nodes.label: Dispatching and context switching
nodes.title: Dispatching and context switching
nodes.description: Dispatching and context switching: are mechanisms used by the operating system to manage the execution of processes and threads, allowing for multitasking and concurrency.

nodes.label: Interprocess communication
nodes.title: Interprocess communication
nodes.description: Interprocess communication: Shared memory, message passing, signals, environment variables, etc

nodes.title: Memory Management
nodes.description: Memory Management:

nodes.title: Review of physical memory, address translation and memory management hardware
nodes.description: Review of physical memory, address translation and memory management hardware:

nodes.title: Impact of memory hierarchy
nodes.description: Impact of memory hierarchy: including cache concept, cache lookup, etcon operating system mechanisms and policy

nodes.title: Logical and physical addressing
nodes.description: Logical and physical addressing:

nodes.title: Concepts of paging, page replacement, thrashing and allocation of pages and frames
nodes.description: Concepts of paging, page replacement, thrashing and allocation of pages and frames:

nodes.title: Allocation/deallocation/storage techniques (algorithms and data structure) performance and flexibility
nodes.description: Allocation/deallocation/storage techniques (algorithms and data structure) performance and flexibility:

nodes.label: Memory Caching and cache coherence
nodes.title: Memory Caching and cache coherence
nodes.description: Memory Caching and cache coherence:

nodes.label: Security mechanisms and concepts in memory management
nodes.title: Security mechanisms and concepts in memory management
nodes.description: Security mechanisms and concepts in memory management: including sandboxing,protection, isolation, and relevant vectors of attack

nodes.label: Protection and Safety
nodes.title: Protection and Safety
nodes.description: Protection and Safety: involve measures to safeguard against unauthorized access, data breaches, and system compromises.

nodes.label: Overview of operating system security mechanisms
nodes.title: Overview of operating system security mechanisms
nodes.description: Overview of operating system security mechanisms: include user authentication, access control, encryption, firewalls, intrusion detection systems (IDS), and antivirus software.

nodes.label: Attacks and antagonism
nodes.title: Attacks and antagonism
nodes.description: Attacks and antagonism: against operating systems can exploit vulnerabilities in software, protocols, or configurations, affecting system stability and security, including issues with scheduling algorithms.

nodes.label: Review of major vulnerabilities in real operating systems
nodes.title: Review of major vulnerabilities in real operating systems
nodes.description: Review of major vulnerabilities in real operating systems: Major vulnerabilities in real operating systems have included buffer overflows, privilege escalation, code injection, and denial-of-service (DoS) attacks.

nodes.label: Operating systems mitigation strategies such as backups
nodes.title: Operating systems mitigation strategies such as backups
nodes.description: Operating systems mitigation strategies such as backups: include regular software updates, patches, backups, disaster recovery plans, and security best practices.

nodes.label: Policy/mechanism separation
nodes.title: Policy/mechanism separation
nodes.description: Policy/mechanism separation: is a security principle that separates the specification of security policies from the mechanisms used to enforce them, reducing the risk of policy misconfiguration or manipulation.

nodes.label: Security methods and devices
nodes.title: Security methods and devices
nodes.description: Security methods and devices: Example concepts: Rings of protection (history from Multics to virtualized x86)

nodes.label: Protection, access control, and authentication
nodes.title: Protection, access control, and authentication
nodes.description: Protection, access control, and authentication: are used to control and manage user access to system resources, ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and availability.

nodes.label: Device Management
nodes.title: Device Management
nodes.description: Device Management: involves controlling and coordinating the operation of hardware devices connected to a computer system, including input/output (I/O) devices like keyboards, mice, and storage devices.

nodes.label: Buffering strategies
nodes.title: Buffering strategies
nodes.description: Buffering strategies: optimize I/O performance by temporarily storing data in memory buffers before transferring it between devices and the CPU, reducing the overhead of frequent I/O operations.

nodes.label: I/O and Storage Management
nodes.title: I/O and Storage Management
nodes.description: I/O and Storage Management: Direct Memory Access and Polled I/O, Memory‐mapped I/Historical and contextual ‐ Persistent storage device management (magnetic, SSD, etc.)

nodes.label: File Systems APl and Implementation
nodes.title: File Systems APl and Implementation
nodes.description: File Systems APl and Implementation: provide interfaces and mechanisms for interacting with file systems, including creating, reading, writing, and deleting files.

nodes.label: Concept of a file
nodes.title: Concept of a file
nodes.description: Concept of a file: represents a named collection of data stored on a storage device, identified by a unique path or file name.

nodes.label: File system mounting
nodes.title: File system mounting
nodes.description: File system mounting: is the process of associating a storage device or partition with a directory in the file system hierarchy, allowing access to its contents.

nodes.label: File access control
nodes.title: File access control
nodes.description: File access control: involves permissions and privileges that determine which users or processes can read, write, or execute files, enforced by the operating system's security mechanisms.

nodes.label: File sharing
nodes.title: File sharing
nodes.description: File sharing: enables multiple users or processes to access and manipulate the same file concurrently, with mechanisms such as file locking to prevent conflicts and ensure data integrity.

nodes.label: Basic file all bation methods
nodes.title: Basic file all bation methods
nodes.description: Basic file all bation methods: include contiguous allocation, linked allocation, and indexed allocation, determining how file data is stored and managed on the storage device.

nodes.label: File system structures comprising file allocation
nodes.title: File system structures comprising file allocation
nodes.description: File system structures comprising file allocation: including various directory structures and methods for uniquely identifying files (name, identified or metadata storage location)

nodes.label: Allocation/deallocation/storage techniques (algorithms and data structure) impact on performance and flexibility
nodes.title: Allocation/deallocation/storage techniques (algorithms and data structure) impact on performance and flexibility
nodes.description: Allocation/deallocation/storage techniques (algorithms and data structure) impact on performance and flexibility:

nodes.label: Free space management
nodes.title: Free space management
nodes.description: Free space management: involves tracking and managing available space on storage devices to allocate it efficiently for new files and avoid fragmentation.

nodes.label: Implementation of directories tsegment and track file location
nodes.title: Implementation of directories tsegment and track file location
nodes.description: Implementation of directories tsegment and track file location:

nodes.label: Advanced File systems
nodes.title: Advanced File systems
nodes.description: Advanced File systems: include features such as partitioning, which divides storage devices into logical segments, and mount/unmount operations to attach/detach file systems to/from the directory hierarchy.

nodes.label: File systems
nodes.title: File systems
nodes.description: File systems: partitioning, mount/unmount, virtual file systems

nodes.label: In-depth implementation techniques
nodes.title: In-depth implementation techniques
nodes.description: In-depth implementation techniques: involve data structures, algorithms, and optimizations used to manage file systems efficiently, including indexing, caching, and compression.

nodes.label: Memory-mapped files
nodes.title: Memory-mapped files
nodes.description: Memory-mapped files: enable direct memory access to files, facilitating efficient data exchange between memory and storage.

nodes.label: Special-purpose file systems
nodes.title: Special-purpose file systems
nodes.description: Special-purpose file systems: are tailored for specific use cases, such as network file systems (NFS), distributed file systems (DFS), and encrypted file systems.

nodes.label: Naming, searching, acces, backups
nodes.title: Naming, searching, acces, backups
nodes.description: Naming, searching, acces, backups:

nodes.label: Journaling and log-structured file systems
nodes.title: Journaling and log-structured file systems
nodes.description: Journaling and log-structured file systems: enhance reliability and recoverability by logging changes to file systems, enabling fast crash recovery and preventing data loss in the event of system failures.

nodes.label: Virtualization
nodes.title: Virtualization
nodes.description: Virtualization: leverages software to create virtual instances of hardware resources, allowing multiple operating systems or applications to run independently on the same physical hardware.

nodes.label: Using virtualization and isolation tachieve protection and predictable performance
nodes.title: Using virtualization and isolation tachieve protection and predictable performance
nodes.description: Using virtualization and isolation tachieve protection and predictable performance:

nodes.label: Advanced paging and virtual memory
nodes.title: Advanced paging and virtual memory
nodes.description: Advanced paging and virtual memory: manage memory resources dynamically, swapping data between physical memory and storage to optimize performance and provide the illusion of abundant memory.

nodes.label: Virtual file systems and virtual devices
nodes.title: Virtual file systems and virtual devices
nodes.description: Virtual file systems and virtual devices: abstract physical storage and hardware components, presenting a unified interface to applications and operating systems.

nodes.label: Thrashing
nodes.title: Thrashing
nodes.description: Thrashing: occurs when a system spends a significant amount of time swapping data between memory and storage, resulting in degraded performance due to excessive paging activity.

nodes.label: Containers
nodes.title: Containers
nodes.description: Containers: provide lightweight, portable, and isolated environments for running applications, encapsulating dependencies and configurations to ensure consistency across different computing environments.

nodes.label: Real-time and Embedded Systems
nodes.title: Real-time and Embedded Systems
nodes.description: Real-time and Embedded Systems: involve computing systems designed to respond to external events or inputs within specified time constraints

nodes.label: Process and task scheduling
nodes.title: Process and task scheduling
nodes.description: Process and task scheduling: ensuring timely execution of critical tasks.

nodes.label: Deadlines and real-time issues
nodes.title: Deadlines and real-time issues
nodes.description: Deadlines and real-time issues: refer to the time constraints imposed on tasks or processes, with deadlines indicating when tasks must be completed to maintain system correctness or performance.

nodes.label: Low-latency/soft real-time" vs "hard real time"
nodes.title: Low-latency/soft real-time" vs "hard real time"
nodes.description: Low-latency/soft real-time" vs "hard real time": Low-latency/soft real-time systems prioritize responsiveness and predictability but can tolerate occasional missed deadlines, while hard real-time systems require absolute adherence to deadlines to avoid catastrophic failures.

nodes.label: Fault Tolerance
nodes.title: Fault Tolerance
nodes.description: Fault Tolerance: ensure system reliability by detecting, isolating, and recovering from hardware or software failures, with approaches including redundancy, error detection and correction, and graceful degradation.

nodes.label: Reliable and available systems
nodes.title: Reliable and available systems
nodes.description: Reliable and available systems: maintain high levels of uptime and service availability, employing redundancy, failover, and recovery mechanisms to minimize downtime and data loss.

nodes.label: Software and hardware approaches taddress tolerance (RAID)
nodes.title: Software and hardware approaches taddress tolerance (RAID)
nodes.description: Software and hardware approaches taddress tolerance (RAID):

nodes.label: Social, Ethical and Professional topics
nodes.title: Social, Ethical and Professional topics
nodes.description: Social, Ethical and Professional topics: include considerations of privacy, security, accessibility, and ethical implications of technology use and development.

nodes.label: Open source in operating systems
nodes.title: Open source in operating systems
nodes.description: Open source in operating systems: involves collaborative development and sharing of source code, fostering innovation, transparency, and community-driven software development.

nodes.label: End‐of‐life issues with sunsetting operating systems
nodes.title: End‐of‐life issues with sunsetting operating systems
nodes.description: End‐of‐life issues with sunsetting operating systems: refer to the discontinuation of support and updates for outdated or obsolete operating systems
